Dear Cody Akers:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
January 15, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department
of human services, the equivalent state or
2

Canadian provincial agency, or equivalent
agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect.
The documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment and
every 12 months thereafter.
One of eleven new employees did not have a central registry (CR) completed 30
days prior to hire. As of date of audit, the CR still had not been completed and
facility was informed staff could not continue working with the youth until results
came back.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report dated 1/24/24; CAP approved 1/31/24

V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The facility submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during the period
of review, which was a result of their 2024 renewal inspection. Compliance with
the CAP is as follows: The facility received violations for Rule 113(1)(i) regarding
central registry clearances, and Rule 113(1)(j) regarding annual employee
evaluations. To mitigate the issues, the facility created a new hire checklist,
human resources had a meeting to discuss requirements, and the program
supervisor created a tracking sheet in excel for annual evaluations.
Financial Overview
There were no concerns based on review of the facility’s financial audit and budget.
3

PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted they need to improve the process of central registry
clearances since they had a repeat violation for Rule 113(1)(i) on this audit. They
are looking into developing further tools, processes, and meetings with human
resources to determine the barriers and solutions. Chief Administrator reported
things are going well at the facility and they have a good team. They had a difficult
youth from November-December 2024, which caused a lot of stress on staff, as
well as youth at the facility. CA reported he is still working through and addressing
the barriers and requirements the new MDHHS contract has had on their facility.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported they enjoy working at the facility. They recently had a difficult youth,
and staff navigated the situation well, with resilience and patience, which was
awesome to see. They have a great team, and even with a lot of new staff,
everyone shows they want to be there. They feel supported by their peers,
supervisors and upper management. Supervisors and upper management always
make themselves available and are open to feedback. The collaboration they've
had with other units, such as nursing, has been amazing and they feel supported in
that regard as well.
Youth reported they like it at the facility. Staff are nice and provide support. They
like having the ability to choose and cook meals with staff support. They like having
their own space, and like that it feels more like a home than a facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on January 15, 2025, and there were no
concerns noted.
4

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
